title: Marcos Calderón
text:
Marcos Calderón (11 July 1928 – 8 December 1987) was a Peruvian <a href="football%20%28soccer%29">football</a> coach. During his tenure the <a href="Peru%20national%20football%20team">Selección de fútbol de Perú</a> won the <a href="Copa%20Am%C3%A9rica%201975">Copa América 1975</a> and reached the second round of the <a href="1978%20World%20Cup">1978 World Cup</a>. He was born in <a href="Lima">Lima</a> in 1928 and died when he was coach to <a href="Alianza%20Lima">Alianza Lima</a> in a terrible <a href="1987%20Alianza%20Lima%20air%20disaster">aviation crash</a> that occurred on 8 December 1987 that killed most of the team's promising squad.
Coaching career.
Calderon was a football player during the 1950s. A few years after his playing retirement, he began coaching.
Several titles were won during his coaching tenure with significant Peruvian clubs, such as: <a href="Universitario%20de%20Deportes">Universitario de Deportes</a>, <a href="Sport%20Boys">Sport Boys</a>, and <a href="Sporting%20Cristal">Sporting Cristal</a>. His successes led to becoming coach of the <a href="Peru%20national%20football%20team">Selección de fútbol de Perú</a>.
Alianza Lima air disaster.
Calderon coached <a href="Alianza%20Lima">Alianza Lima</a>, developed several significant players and won several titles. Much of the team was relatively young. Calderon had faith in his players, and many of them played on national team. Onboard a plane for an away match of the <a href="Peruvian%20First%20Division">Peruvian League</a> Alianza Lima, it crashed; Calderon and the entire team Alianza were killed. Several on the team were national team players.
